conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process, we need to calculate the work done in each segment of the cycle and then sum them up.

The work done by the gas in a cyclic process can be calculated using the area under the p-V (pressure-volume) curve for each segment of the cycle. The total work done by the gas over one complete cycle is given by the net area enclosed by the cycle.
Segment A to B is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
Segment B to C is an isochoric process (constant volume).
Segment C to A is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
Volume changes from V_A = 2 L to V_B = 2 L.

premise: Pressure P_A = P_B = 4 x 10^5 Pa. Volume changes from V_A = 2 L to V_B = 2 L.
conclusion: Work done W_AB = P ΔV = 4 x 10^5 Pa x (2 L - 2 L) = 0.
Volume remains constant V_B = V_C = 2 L.
Pressure changes from P_B = 4 x 10^5 Pa to P_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa.

premise: Volume remains constant V_B = V_C = 2 L.
conclusion: Work done W_BC = 0 because volume is constant.
Volume changes from V_C = 2 L to V_A = 5 L.

premise: Pressure P_C = P_A = 1 x 10^5 Pa. Volume changes from V_C = 2 L to V_A = 5 L.
conclusion: Work done W_CA = P ΔV = 1 x 10^5 Pa x (5 L - 2 L) = 3 x 10^5 J.
Total work done by the gas W_total = W_AB + W_BC + W_CA = 3 x 10^5 J.
